title: How to Make Artichoke Dip

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350ºF.
steps.description: Artichoke dip cooks quickly, and you can even throw it in before the oven has finished heating if you prepare it in time.

steps.headline: Spray a large oven-safe dish with cooking spray.
steps.description: If you do not have spray, drip a little olive oil on a paper towel and wipe it along the sides and bottom of your dish. This will prevent the dip from sticking later on.

steps.headline: Cut the artichoke hearts into large, course pieces.
steps.description: Make sure you drain the liquid out of the can before cutting. You want chunks around than the size of quarters.

steps.headline: Finely chop the garlic and spinach and add them to your artichokes.
steps.description: These pieces will be slightly smaller. The finer you chop them, the less noticeable they will be in the final dish. For vegetable-based dips, chop your green onions, roasted red peppers, or extra spinach and add them as well.

steps.headline: Mix your "wet ingredients," like mayonnaise, cream cheese, and sour cream, in a separate bowl.
steps.description:
While you can experiment with different combinations, you want between 1 1/2 and 2 cups of liquid total. Mayonnaise is the most common wet ingredient. For classic dip, use 1 1/2 cups mayonnaise and 8 ounces cream cheese. For rich dip, use 1 cup mayonnaise, 1/2 cup sour cream, and 16 ounces cream cheese
For lite dip, use 1/3 cup lite mayonnaise and 8 ounces lite cream cheese.

steps.headline: Add the vegetables and Parmesan cheese to the wet ingredients and stir.
steps.description: You want everything to be well mixed and coated with cream. If you are adding other cheeses, like shredded mozzarella, add them now.

steps.headline: Add salt, pepper, and spices to taste.
steps.description:
Artichoke dip is a simple dish that is easily customized with a few spices or changes. Don't worry about "ruining" the cooking process, as from here you will mostly just heat the dip up. Crushed red pepper, cayenne, or hot sauce makes a spicier dip
Lemon juice and dill give the dip a slight Mediterranean flavor.

steps.headline: Spoon the uncooked dip into the baking dish.
steps.description: Leave at least 1/2 an inch between the rim of the dish and the tip, as it will bubble up as it cooks.

steps.headline: Cook the dish for 30 minutes, or until the top is golden-brown.
steps.description: Be sure to check your dip periodically, and be careful removing the dip when it is finished. If you smell smoke or the top is burning, remove the dip immediately and turn off the oven.

steps.headline: Serve your dip after it has cooled.
steps.description: After it has cooled for 5-10 minutes, serve your artichoke dip with something to dip into it -- like pita chips, crackers, cut vegetables, or sliced baguettes.

steps.headline: Toss in a can of flaked crab meat for a decadent dip.
steps.description: Make a hot artichoke-crab hybrid dip that will be the toast of every party on the block. Simply mix it in with the artichoke hearts for an absolutely killer dip. You can also add 1/2 cup pimentos, green chilies, and/or sliced almonds to take your dish to the next level.

steps.headline: Consider roasted garlic for a toasty punch in your dip.
steps.description: Peel 4-6 cloves of garlic, leaving them whole. Coat them in a light layer of olive oil and place them on a baking sheet. Place them in the oven as ti pre-heats, checking periodically. Once the outsides are golden brown, flip them and give them another 2-3 minutes. Remove when done and slice, then toss with the rest of your ingredients.

steps.headline: Try a chili-cheese dip for some southwest flavor.
steps.description: Simply substitute in 1 cup cheddar cheese for Parmesan and/or mozzarella. Once you've mixed everything in, dice up 5-6 green chilies and toss them with the artichoke hearts.

steps.headline: Put your dip into a bread-bowl for hand-held appetizers.
steps.description: To do so, use a sheet of pastry dough, or some pre-made biscuit dough. Cut the dough and press it into the bottom of a muffin pan, indenting the center 1/2 inch so that you can fill it. Make your dip, then fill up the center of each mini dough-bowl. Cook, as normal, for 10-15 minutes, or until the dough is golden brown.

steps.headline: Make a cold-dip for a quick, easy appetizer.
steps.description: If it's too hot to bake, or you simply want to get a dip made quickly. you can easily adapt the recipe for a chilled version. To do so, cut the mayonnaise down to 1/2 cup, then mash the hearts with a fork before mixing. You can also put the entire mixture in a food processor. Chill until you're ready to serve.

text:
Making Classic Dip (With Optional Ingredients) Preheat your oven to 350ºF. Artichoke dip cooks quickly, and you can even throw it in before the oven has finished heating if you prepare it in time. Spray a large oven-safe dish with cooking spray. If you do not have spray, drip a little olive oil on a paper towel and wipe it along the sides and bottom of your dish. This will prevent the dip from sticking later on. Cut the artichoke hearts into large, course pieces. Make sure you drain the liquid out of the can before cutting. You want chunks around than the size of quarters. Finely chop the garlic and spinach and add them to your artichokes. These pieces will be slightly smaller. The finer you chop them, the less noticeable they will be in the final dish. For vegetable-based dips, chop your green onions, roasted red peppers, or extra spinach and add them as well. Mix your "wet ingredients," like mayonnaise, cream cheese, and sour cream, in a separate bowl. While you can experiment with different combinations, you want between 1 1/2 and 2 cups of liquid total. Mayonnaise is the most common wet ingredient. For classic dip, use 1 1/2 cups mayonnaise and 8 ounces cream cheese. For rich dip, use 1 cup mayonnaise, 1/2 cup sour cream, and 16 ounces cream cheese
For lite dip, use 1/3 cup lite mayonnaise and 8 ounces lite cream cheese. Add the vegetables and Parmesan cheese to the wet ingredients and stir. You want everything to be well mixed and coated with cream. If you are adding other cheeses, like shredded mozzarella, add them now. Add salt, pepper, and spices to taste. Artichoke dip is a simple dish that is easily customized with a few spices or changes. Don't worry about "ruining" the cooking process, as from here you will mostly just heat the dip up. Crushed red pepper, cayenne, or hot sauce makes a spicier dip
Lemon juice and dill give the dip a slight Mediterranean flavor. Spoon the uncooked dip into the baking dish. Leave at least 1/2 an inch between the rim of the dish and the tip, as it will bubble up as it cooks. Cook the dish for 30 minutes, or until the top is golden-brown. Be sure to check your dip periodically, and be careful removing the dip when it is finished. If you smell smoke or the top is burning, remove the dip immediately and turn off the oven. Serve your dip after it has cooled. After it has cooled for 5-10 minutes, serve your artichoke dip with something to dip into it -- like pita chips, crackers, cut vegetables, or sliced baguettes. Variations Toss in a can of flaked crab meat for a decadent dip. Make a hot artichoke-crab hybrid dip that will be the toast of every party on the block. Simply mix it in with the artichoke hearts for an absolutely killer dip. You can also add 1/2 cup pimentos, green chilies, and/or sliced almonds to take your dish to the next level. Consider roasted garlic for a toasty punch in your dip. Peel 4-6 cloves of garlic, leaving them whole. Coat them in a light layer of olive oil and place them on a baking sheet. Place them in the oven as ti pre-heats, checking periodically. Once the outsides are golden brown, flip them and give them another 2-3 minutes. Remove when done and slice, then toss with the rest of your ingredients. Try a chili-cheese dip for some southwest flavor. Simply substitute in 1 cup cheddar cheese for Parmesan and/or mozzarella. Once you've mixed everything in, dice up 5-6 green chilies and toss them with the artichoke hearts. Put your dip into a bread-bowl for hand-held appetizers. To do so, use a sheet of pastry dough, or some pre-made biscuit dough. Cut the dough and press it into the bottom of a muffin pan, indenting the center 1/2 inch so that you can fill it. Make your dip, then fill up the center of each mini dough-bowl. Cook, as normal, for 10-15 minutes, or until the dough is golden brown. Make a cold-dip for a quick, easy appetizer. If it's too hot to bake, or you simply want to get a dip made quickly. you can easily adapt the recipe for a chilled version. To do so, cut the mayonnaise down to 1/2 cup, then mash the hearts with a fork before mixing. You can also put the entire mixture in a food processor. Chill until you're ready to serve.
